subject: Mathematics – Grade 9
learning_competency: The learner identifies and verifies sets of integers that satisfy the Pythagorean Theorem and determine whether they form right triangles.

sections.purpose: This module aims to develop the learners' ability to identify, verify, and apply triangle triples using the Pythagorean Theorem. It is designed to reinforce mastery of right triangle relationships and prepare learners for solving higher-level geometric problems.
learning_objectives: Identify the parts of a right triangle correctly.
Determine whether a given set of three integers forms a triangle triple.
Solve and analyze problems involving triangle triples accurately.

theorem.statement: In any right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

section_ii_theorem_and_triples.theorem_definition: The Pythagorean Theorem is a fundamental rule in geometry stating that in any right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides. If a and b are the legs and c is the hypotenuse, then:
section_ii_theorem_and_triples.theorem_application: This formula allows us to find the length of a missing side of a right triangle.
section_ii_theorem_and_triples.from_theorem_intro: When the Pythagorean Theorem is satisfied using positive whole numbers, the set of numbers (a, b, c) is called a Pythagorean triple. These are special sets of integers that form the sides of a right triangle.
section_ii_theorem_and_triples.connection: Every Pythagorean triple comes from the Pythagorean Theorem. While the theorem applies to all right triangles, triples are the cases where all three sides are whole numbers, making them easy to work with and remember.
section_ii_theorem_and_triples.definition: A triangle triple, also known as a Pythagorean triple, is a set of three positive whole numbers a, b, and c that can represent the side lengths of a right triangle. These numbers satisfy the equation:
where_bullets: a and b are the legs of the triangle
c is the hypotenuse, the longest side opposite the right angle
section_ii_theorem_and_triples.conclusion: If the equation is satisfied, then the three numbers form a right triangle.

terms.definition: a triangle with one right (90°) angle
the two shorter sides of a right triangle
the longest side opposite the right angle
three whole numbers that satisfy the theorem

subterms.definition: a triple with no common factor greater than 1
subterms.detail: Cannot divide all numbers by the same whole number greater than 1

subterms.definition: a multiple of a basic triple that has a common factor
subterms.detail: Can divide all numbers by the same number

section_iv_procedure.intro: To determine whether three numbers form a triangle triple, follow these steps carefully:

steps.title: Arrange the numbers in increasing order.
steps.detail: Write the numbers from smallest to largest. The largest number will be the hypotenuse (c).

steps.title: Identify the parts of the formula.
Add the squares of the two smaller numbers.
Compare both sides of the equation.
conditions: If a² + b² = c², then the set is a triangle triple.
If a² + b² ≠ c², then the set is NOT a triangle triple.

procedure_steps: Arrange the numbers in increasing order. The largest number will be the hypotenuse (c).
Identify a and b as the smaller numbers and c as the largest number.
Write the equation a² + b² = c².
Add the squares of the two smaller numbers.
Compare both sides of the equation.
